question: Which motion of Earth causes stars to appear to move across the sky at night?

content.source_1: Over the course of a single night at most latitudes, stars rise in the east, arc across the sky, and set in the west relative to the local horizon; this repeated, daily pattern is widely observed.
content.source_2: Astronomers refer to the apparent daily motion of celestial objects across the sky relative to the horizon as diurnal motion.
content.source_3: Earth rotates once every approximately 23 hours 56 minutes relative to the stars (a sidereal day), which makes the celestial sphere appear to rotate westward and produces diurnal motion.
content.source_4: Earth travels around the Sun at roughly 30 km/s, so an observer’s position in space changes continuously as Earth completes one orbit each year.
content.source_5: When an observer moves, the apparent direction to distant objects shifts (e.g., parallax and aberration), so the observer’s motion can produce apparent displacement of stars in the sky.
content.source_6: Long-exposure night-sky photographs show star trails as circular arcs around the celestial poles over hours, indicating a steady, systematic apparent motion of the stars.
